nP3uieCy75Ef-zHfHPevHg.text: The poor reviews here are mainly due to driver error. I always go with  Chinese friends, who steer my choices. They often smack my hand when I reach for certain items, "don't get that here". Often these are the best looking items. It was explained to me that Dim Sum choices must be traditional Dim Sum items, which we do not know about. No French pastries, no shiny desserts, no fried meat piles. I can't lend you my friends but I can help you get support in successful management of these tyrant cart ladies. The steel beer mugs are fun, too.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Tofu skin wrap
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Azuki bean ball
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Eggplant

6A3eryfWyxJjEwgRiCAGwA.text: Your usual Chinese restaurant. It's been around since forever and I've heard of this place a thousand times and more but haven't had a chance to check it out. There is no menu, you just pick out stuff from ladies who stroll around the cart full of food. I honestly prefer a regular, sit down and eat restaurant but this was quite an experience. Not sure if I'll ever go back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Chicken feet
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Swan cream puffs. delicious!

DYe0opqK8j7ghXaVEoI9eQ.text: Wow prices have gone up a lot! Sweet and sour pork $12! Chicken fried rice $12 Not sure why they think they warrant these prices! Food is decent, but factor in the price it's out there!

g7FdSZbrCNpeO5LJVH2i1Q.text: Came here one night with the fam and we got two different kinds of whole chicken from their ready to serve hot food area.  It smells good enough.  We took it home, chopped it up, and started to eat it.    About 20 minutes later I started to heat up like a teapot, the world started to spin, the trees were talking about equal rights, my stomach was turning, the roaches were painting with the colours of the wind, sparks were flying, and for a moment I thought I was dying.    I suddenly had the urge to run to the restroom and so I did, and there my body decided to flush itself out!  I was sweating all over, my noise was running, my eyes were watering, I was throwing up all while doing a one and a two all at the same time.  It was a horrible case of food poisoning.  I was out of commission for three days, 4 hours, 27 minutes, and 11 seconds.    Never again did I went back to this place, took a long while before I started to eat chicken again.  What an experience!  I heard the restaurant side was good, I'm not risking it though!

SO2fPvKuQs2LaUQNEfs2Yg.text: Good stuff here!!!  We've been going to Phoenix Palace for about 3 years.  Although they are not up to a Yank Sing level, they are about the best in town for the Phoenix area.  AND, they have soup dumplings!  Love soup dumplings. . .  Great service, my daughter and I arrived early and we almost had to hide under the table when all the steam carts converged on our table.  Looked like bees around a hive.  Everything we ordered was flavorful and hot.   Take away is great too.  We often phone in a Sunday order and enjoy a tableful of Shu Mai, Har Gow, and about a dozen other delicious dumplings and plates.  BBQ pork is excellent, as are the Shrimp rolls.  Enjoy

XwgeqNX-8BRIUgFrW5l91Q.text: This is the first dim sum place I've found in this area, so I'm not sure how they compare to others here.  I have a pretty high bar for dim sum, but I have to say this place is great for dim sum!  I've lived in a lot of places around the country and have tried many dim sum restaurants, but this is one of the best ones.  Wide selection, tasty food, and not as crowded as many dim sum restaurants.  We loved every food item we ordered!

YpU5a2eWT9WZMrM5jpeZ3A.text: The best chinese food in the valley. Im used to good Chinese food. Born and raised in a chinese family in new york city, there was never a shortage of good authentic chinese food. I was quickly disappointed when i moved into the valley, until i found phoenix palace. My go to chinese restaurant.   Dim sum is also the best in the valley. All the baking is done in house and can compete with the best.

9tZhhld9c2m7rHPUkpCXcA.text: Food is delicious, my favorite place for my Chinese food cravings. Portions are large, prices are maybe a little higher than other restaurants but I love the food so don't mind paying a few $$ extra

FXLR0shclGNio9YmNyf0tg.text: Takeout wasn't fast, but they did apologize as they had to make the rice cakes.  Service wasn't the best, but they weren't outright rude.  The woman at the cash register did open up became more friendly and outgoing as she packed up the part of our order that was taking a while.  Shrimp ball: Bland, not crunchy enough, probably my least favorite   Shoumai: Great texture, very meaty.  BBQ pork bun: More savory than most, a lot less sugary and more authentic than the hot pink varieties many places have.  Really great.  Spareribs: Very moist but very fatty, my second least favorite.  Baked custard bun: Extremely good!  Fluffy and really good when warm.  Not too sweet,  Egg tart: Now here's where the sugar is.  Very sweet but good.  Sesame seed ball: Nice mild sweetness level of black bean inside, but they were too crispy/overcooked.  I'm still not sure whether is was the sweet or sticky rice cake, but think it was sweet...the white dessert ones...were very light, chewy, and definitely a great dessert without the heaviness of custard or being deep fried.

GtMGmlIzaMy6S2IUKjjIzg.text: Solid dim sum place. Hai gow shut Mai pai gwat and Shen feung.  Quick service carts and good prices.

DhwI4UscSV-_CkCN7xzLKQ.text: What's not to love about dim sum? You can pick and choose any dish and they're small portions so you're able to try a variety of items for a reasonable price. Its kind of like tapas style, except dim sum comes ready-made and ready-to-eat to you in carts pushed by people. This place is busy on the weekends, but proves to be an excellent place to enjoy this style of dining. Check out the photo to see some of the things I ate (BBQ pork buns, egg tart custard, Chinese broccoli, shu Mai, soup dumpling, etc)....I passed on the chicken feet.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Dim sum: soup dumpling, egg custard, BBQ pork buns! Yum!

ugNfYZDTKxvV4-DlCNCD4Q.text: Came here for dim sum on a Saturday morning around 11:00 am.  The restaurant wasn't too busy at that time but it was pretty packed by the time that we finished eating.    There's a good variety of dim sum items available.  Prices are reasonable.  We had the shrimp dumplings, lotus leaf rice, barbeque pork buns, pork and shrimp dumplings, tofu skin roll, chicken feet, tripe, beef balls, rice noodle rolls, and savory stuffed dumplings.  The food was decent flavor-wise but the downside was that everything was only lukewarm except for the savory stuffed dumplings.  We got the savory stuffed dumplings towards the end of our meal.  Had we started eating a little later when the restaurant was busier, we probably would have had hotter food since there would be higher turnover.  My favorite dishes were the savory stuffed dumplings, tripe, shrimp dumplings, and lotus leaf rice.

4k-vl092O04hOSCMDpIvrQ.text: I always get the dim sum to go. There food is good. And friendly service. Almost everything we get is pretty good and there pricing is great. Shu mai is yummy.

zAp6CcvU6kuiBb9HpgokPA.text: My mom came from Guangzhou China, she likes dim sum a lot, it's the nearest place we can have dim sum in Chandler. We went this restaurant many times, our favorite items tested not the same each time, sometime good, sometime test not as good as we expected. They have a great potential of improvement.

U7CNQpCv4yKU4o7P01IpoQ.text: Really not good at all. My wife and i brought the kids and were excited due to all the good yelp reviews. Every dish went from bland to plain bad. The service was good and the restaurant was clean but not one of the 4 dishes we ordered was any good and the main dish was plain bad. Will not return.

tiNZIREy4wUL_RGTMRd_ZA.text: Awesome Dim Sum! Huge selection! We have been searching for somewhere as good as The Golden Buddha since they closed... we found somewhere so much better!   The BBQ pork noodles are divine, the kids love the chicken feet! Have not had one bad item here.   Can't wait to go back to try more as there are so many kinds of Dim Sum, there is no way to eat them all on the same visit.   Well worth the drive to Chandler from North Phoenix.

p2a1QYEbDTIL8mJ2Tg3f2Q.text: This is the second time I took my family to Phoenix Palace to enjoy dimsum. We drove all the way from Flagstaff to feast on hakaw/shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, sticky rice with pork, stewed chicken feet, curried tendon, seaweed, congee and sesame balls. It was worth the 2.5 hr drive and skipping breakfast.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Yummilicious meal! hakaw/shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, sticky rice with pork, stewed chicken feet, curried tendon and sesame balls

rWg2RouRn7fd4JBqk9dVMw.text: I've been to all of the dim sum houses in the Phoenix area looking for one to replace my old Chicago favorite. I've yet to find anything in Arizona that even comes close to the freshness and amazing quality of what I'm used to.   That being said, during the 3 years that I've lived in Arizona, I have seen the quality of dim sum that Phoenix Palace serves increase--their shrimp dishes used to be completely inedible, as were many of their dishes containing pork. The restaurant is generally clean, but they often do not serve you water unless you personally request it, and it is definitely not filtered/clean/pure water - it tastes like it came from a rusty tap, in my opinion. We prefer their chrysanthemum tea over green, so be sure to make a special request if you want to try it. The one plus side of this location is that their business is steady so they're able to offer a large variety of dim sum.   Given the very few options we have here, this place is one of the better ones, although we prefer Mekong Palace in Mesa--and despite living close to Phoenix Palace, we usually make the longer drive to Mesa for dim sum more similar to the quality that we are used to.

eEX2NB9XpyDJRLaamBpyiw.text: Best Dim-Sum in town. By far the Phoenix Palace has one of the best Dim-sum and menu. The service is always nice and friendly. The restaurant itself is nice and clean. Highly recommend the Singapore Noodles, I can't enough of it. Do yourself a favor and visit this place any day of the week for lunch starting at 10:00 AM. Afterwards take some time to visit some of the other restaurants within the shopping strip and make sure you check out Lei-Lei Supermarket with their great products from all over the world. This is the Walmart of the east. A+

9jnq6ks9EeRfq8_yFS2IRA.text: Dimsum here is great! Happy to find an Asian restaurant that serves good dimsum in Phoenix. Coming from LA I'm spoiled with amazing Chinese food so nothing here is comparable but Phoenix palace gives me what I want when I want and I can't complain.

Otd3E4Uzp9cTWcjcdylNcQ.text: I used to live in Phoenix and ate here for Dim Sum or dinner all the time. Now that I live in Houston, I try to visit every time I go back to Phoenix. The food is delicious, the prices are reasonable, and the service is always friendly and efficient. What a great place for a meal by yourself or with friends and family. Highly recommend!

Xqic_L6Z0ev05sjLsAo83Q.text: I love dim sum but, the food was okay. The service was not that great. It was very hard communicating with the servers and witnesses. They didn't seem to care. The prices were a bit high for dim sum. I got charged with an "guest" fee of 0.65 cent. What?!? So... I was charged for bringing my husband along with me?!? Wait... That doesn't make sense at all. My husband did not eat anything but did ordered an iced tea in which I was charged $2.79 for... so I don't understand what the "guest" fee of $0.65 cent was for. I'm also positive that they overcharged me. I only ate the a small cup soup, beef ripe and  shrimp dumplings and I drank water. My bill was $16.10? Wow. I won't be back. Can someone please tell me why they charged me a "guest fee"? Ugh.

OYJMo8cl0WufoqePTLZJQQ.text: Based on a recommendation and okay reviews, we recently gave Phoenix Palace a try.  Got there on a Saturday afternoon around 1pm.  The place was very busy and Dim Sum carts were everywhere.  The Dim Sum cart ladies were blunt and unfriendly to us and the nearby tables; not to mention they were pushy with their fellow cart colleagues.  One actually shoved her coworker's cart right out of the aisle with her cart and headed to the next table to sell her food.  As customers finished their meals and started leaving, the carts never came by our table again until we made a specific request.  In addition to the poor service, the food wasn't nearly as good as other Dim Sum places in the area.  The food we received was fine, but the selection was surprisingly dismal & quite limited, and special orders took well over 20 minutes.   First time I've left a Dim Sum restaurant feeling hungry.  Won't be back and can't recommend this place.

FZsA1J-El3ytuG6dpsh4dg.text: First time checking in but We've been comming here g or at least give years.  It's very "authentic " everyyhing... The push cart ladies 89% of whom all Speak mostly chinese.. Tastes better than China wall.. I p the roasthe great Wall back c k in phoenix... Thumbs up price us reasonable,  standard dimsum selection, all the right sauces, chrysanthemum tea.. Everything.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. To go menu

YxVVDa_VPYrNJ5thrsylhw.text: July, 2019 - much better maybe because we got seated up front!  We noticed when seated in the back room service is slightly different and possibly slower.  Many of the items I love (shrimp and peppers, eggplant and a few others you should probably order up front because for the 1.5 hours we were there, both times I never saw them).  On that note the rice flour shrimp rolls has to be ordered as well.  But the good news they have them!  1) Shrimp rolls: very good today and fresh! 2) Shrimp crispy roll: I love the small versions.  Theses were huge and every bite had 3-5 little shrimps.  Not a hit for us but crispy! 3) Steamed Pork & shrimp dumplings: I can't have them (mushrooms) but always my sons favorite! 4) Steamed shrimp dumplings: My favorite when the shrimp is fresh and they were.  Hint: 1st timers mix some soy sauce and Sriracha together for a dip! 5) Custom order: Fried rice with chicken. No taste at all.  Pass. 6) Spicy crispy chicken: a little too hot for us but really good. 7) Special order: Green pepper with shrimp (and the black bean sauce): yummy! 8) Sesame balls (red bean paste inside, best when hot).  Note; squish in half to get two beautiful even pieces!

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Steamed shrimp dumplings
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Steamed pork and shrimp dumpling
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Chicken fried rice

Y9BNqmY2k6skd9SteiDtEw.text: IF you want to have dimsum ,  order to go.  Food is good enough.  If you want to dine in - set your expectation way low lunch hours..  I tried to like it here again because there is now only one dimsum this side of town as the other one across the street just closed. Haven't been here in a year and now I remember why.  Customer service - rude,  dismissive and didn't care it was 105f inside.  Please invest in a host that makes you feel welcome :)  You guys will survive because there is no competition.  One day your customers won't care that they have no choice and just stop tolerating it.  You still have time - get better please - shame to have you closed .

HDPgPeEi8h_GBopc82uZTg.text: I was looking for authentic Chinese and the dinner menu/food was just American Chinese blah. Noodles were fine  but Kung pow and veg was just sugar and soy sauce goo.  If you like American Chinese you'll probably like it. Not for me.  I'll be back to try the dim sum though.

5pRNC6f9f-dP5XnqMaBbkQ.text: This place is still number one in my book!  It was father's day, and I was really looking forward to catching up with all my daughters. They were kind enough to take off from their busy schedule to drive from all over town just to meet up for one afternoon.  I do have dreadful memories of this place, and the prolonged waits. But, they have since improved upon that train wreck of system, and they now allow reservations for Dim Sum weekends.  It was so surprising, and refreshing to walk up at the appointed time, and be seated right away. No fuss. No muss. No prolonged waits in the tiny lobby.   They put our party of 6 at a large table, with more than adequate room to satiate our desire to order everything that is presented to us. I do recall that they used to have a more varied Dim Sum menu. It seems that they have pared down some over the years. My last visit here was nearly 5 years ago.  The place was bustling, and rightfully so! The food is still spectacular. We had the XLB's, Siomai, roast duck, chow mein, fried shrimp, steamed pork buns, and, of course, various desserts!  Service was excellent as always. This place continues to be a favorite of ours.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

kljhs4Xod-a3stsGA9ziiQ.text: This is another one of my favorite places to go for dim sum. We order our usual haw gao, siu mei, shrimp cheng fun, sticky rice, booloo bao (pineapple bun), and don tot (egg tart).   I have to say, the service is excellent. We asked for shrimp cheng fun from the lady with the haw gao, siu mei, sticky rice cart and she got the lady who had the cheng fun!

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Dim sum!

ibVT1b4v9zg97tMH9FrlUg.text: Ive been hearing so much rage about this place and how good it is!  So we were in the neighborhood since its right next to our grocery store - Lee Lees.    It was on a weekday and not during a crazy lunch hour.  I was excited to see they have rice cake but, when I took a few bites it was pretty dry and its probably because it was sitting outside all day - just my guess. So I didnt finish eating the rice cake.  Their simple dim sum that we had which was their chow mein, Pork hash, shrimp dumplings and etc - they were all good and the customer service were nice but, slacked in water service and busy cleaning up.   Nice place for a one time stop and enjoyed some of their decor!

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Yummm... Dim Sum
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Rice cake- it was kinda dry (sitting outside)
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Big pot! Place a monetary coin or dollar bill and you will flourish with success

b11_ArirOBq4DX1ZvdlnFg.text: Best place for dim sum in the East Valley!  Go early if you don't want to wait in line for the table. Once you get seated, many carts of food would rush to your table.   It is easily to make my table full with food in a matter of few minutes. I love the atmosphere and the food here. I love to enjoy variety of steamed dumplings with chili oil and soy sauce. I like their custard bun and egg tart. Noodle and veggie are delicious.   I always packed some leftovers and enjoy them later on that day or the next day. They have a counter for you to order if you won't want to eat in.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. First round

cvAv1FZOrPRkg8G0posDzg.text: So, I love dim sum & everything about it.  The rolling carts, the selection, the conversation, trying new things, even when I don't know exactly what they are.  It's like a little culinary adventure.    There's a language barrier for me and normally, that's fine.  I get it and I'm respectful because it's my fault I don't speak the language so I try to make it as painless as possible.  There was a wait on Saturday, which is expected.  They were busy so I wasn't expecting prime service, I get it.    It started with our host, who sat us at our table and asked if we wanted water and immediately walked away without waiting for a response.  She returned with our waters and when we asked for hot tea, she rolled her eyes, sighed out loud and walked to get the tea without asking what kind we would like.  We had to ask twice for cups for the tea.    The ladies pushing the carts were straight up rude and dismissive.  They passed us by several times, then would give us expensive plates that we didn't ask for and assumed we would want.  I came in craving shumai and left overpaying for over cooked noodles and generic deep fried food that I didn't want.  No, I won't be returning to this spot.  I think there's better experiences in dim sum in the world.  The food here wasn't that great and I wouldn't be able to recommend this experience to anyone.

zwesUmJHUOYjUxOWDaZElA.text: This is a larger sized Chinese restaurant that is run like a "mom and pop" place in terms of cost control and cutting corners.  Food is decent for Phoenix.  Dim sum is not refined nor have a big variety, but understandably so for current Phoenix Asian population standards.  The restaurant needs cleaner restrooms and more customer service improvements. Do not go after 1pm for Dim Sum even rhough dim sum is served until 3pm.  The kitchen stops cooking, so customers are only served what is left on the carts, which are left over choices that are either going old (stale bbq buns, hardened pan fried dumpling skins, etc.) or luke warm to cold temperature food.

IODXLm2A1wGjYi9RKCQKAA.text: If you were to imagine a generic dim sum place, Phoenix Palace would be the place that comes to mind.  They serve the standard dishes although some not as good as others.  I had two sticky rices and one was markedly better than the other.  Service is sub-par.  They seated us at a dirty table, didn't give us an order form, and had multiple people ask us if we wanted something to drink but didn't actually bring us anything.  I did notice they were eating off the dim sum cart so maybe it everyone's coffee break.

KZcEizTV1oBBUF1kzbN0-Q.text: We hadn't been to yum cha at Phoenix Palace in years; we remembered not being huge fans, but decided to give it another go because we didn't want to deal with the madness of Mekong. Arriving just after open on Memorial Day, our party of four was immediately seated, and immediately swarmed by the little ladies pushing carts of food around. And by immediate, I mean they swooped before I could even take my seat, so I was left awkwardly standing for a few minutes.   We got a few of our usual dishes and tucked in. The ha gow, usually one of my favorite dim sum dishes, was... abysmal. The wrapper was thick, and the inside was floury and fell apart in your mouth (not in a good way) and didn't even taste like shrimp. The roast duck was probably my favorite dish here, and it was pretty decent. We also had shrimp rice noodle roll, which was not bad. The tofu skin roll was okay, too. The Cantonese soy sauce chow mein was fine; it wasn't super flavorful but it also wasn't drowning in oil, which I always appreciate. The cocktail buns tasted only like coconut and were a little dry.   I'm still a meh on Phoenix Palace. I'd go if everyone else insisted, but would rather brave the crowds at Mekong.

kU_qW98BFwH5iwGVRLF80A.text: Warning: don't ever tried their roast pork, I ordered to go and when I got home I tried a piece not realizing its full of maggots.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. full of Maggots
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. full of Maggots

f520diyt3tfYAx_qlksHwQ.text: Excellent dim sum! Always busy on a Sunday, so either make a reservation or arrive at 10AM. If you arrive at 11AM, then seating time will depend on the size of your party.   Excellent variety of dim sum dishes with plenty of carts making the rounds through the dining room area.   Parking is plentiful even when it is busy.  Phoenix Palace is located in the same shopping center as Lee Lee Market.

b7PyzvuFGdPnQT28YSGBYw.text: I would not even recommend this place for dinner to my worst enemy. Bad is an understatement.  We were craving Chinese for dinner and decided to order to go. We got the sate fried rice, sweet and sour pork, salt and pepper squid, salt and garlic fish, and shrimp lo mein. Not one item tasted decent. The fried rice tasted like old rice that was mixed in with meats. There were huge clumps of white rice all over and no flavor. The only flavor was old stale rice. The lo mein was better but again, no flavor and they only filled up the box half way. The squid had a bitter taste to it and the fish was hard. Oh and the pork.... I was a little upset that their idea of sweet and sour pork was to over fried some pork and place onions and peppers onto it. They didn't even take their time to fry it together a little so that the flavors meld together. The bell pepper and onions tasted so raw and wrong.   And the icing on top of the cake has to be the guy ringing us up. I asked for extra hot chili oil and his reply was I can only give you 3. Okay so me spending 70 bucks for dinner only gets me 3 small measly sauce cups of chili oil?   I absolutely love dim sum here but I would stay away if you want to order off their dinner menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. You dim sum, you win sum

xGMG0vJdmx5gA1gHHy19og.text: This place has really gone down hill with quality and service. Dim Sum is average of you can get the cart ladies to come to your table. We have been coming here for years and will not return after our experience today. Save your money and pick a cleaner place to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

D_-6lbP9fIwgbVg-Duk9iQ.text: My home away from home and favorite to visit or order dim-sum to go on a Saturday or Sunday morning. I grew up eating dim-sum on the weekends when I would have to visit my grandparents in San Francisco, so I'm very much stuck to this routine and try to do it as often as possible.   Whenever my husband and I want dim sum, our first thought is the Phoenix Palace in Chandler! Why? Because there is a great amount of options, the food is delicious and if you want something beyond dim sum you can certainly order that (like a noodle dish or regular lunch/dinner option).   Be aware, this place gets very busy on a Saturday and Sunday. Although this place gets busy they are hustling and you will quickly be seated. If you don't want to sit and eat here, you can always order in advance and pick up to take home; which I'm very guilty of doing a lot.   Just to explain how much this place is home away from home, my grandmother was born and raised in Hong Kong and loves this place. When she comes to visit from the Bay Area she always asks to come here and even hosted a huge family gathering here when my family was in town for my wedding. Yes, my family and I are fans. If you like dim sum and Chinese food, you will be one too.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce  (take-out)
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Har Gow &amp; Shu Mai  (take-out)
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Steamed pork buns  (take-out)

69MQw_RUu0FUfMP1N3FuOQ.text: Phoenix Palace is my favorite dim sum place in the area. But they have their ups and downs in terms of service, food quality, and availability of food depending on the time you go.   Weekends are their busiest days because everybody and their mom (literally) will be there and the wait to be seated can be anywhere from 5-30 minutes. But with the busiest days comes more fresh food because they have to keep up with the demands.   If you go during the weekdays, they're typically not that busy in comparison to the weekends. But with that comes less fresh food because there's not as much demand.   So choose which you prefer? I tend to find weekends to be better even with a little bit slower service because the food is fresher.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

yA3WIC-mo508Maz8_vdbEQ.text: I go to this place to eat their crispy tofu with young bamboo. I have to eat it at least once a month :). I love the young bamboo in the light sauce and the tofu is perfectly crisp. I just add a little hoisin sauce and it's perfect. This is not even a popular dish of the restaurant but something I love. This place is actually popular for their dim sums and I have heard its packed at lunch time even though this place is huge with a lot of seating capacity. Since I am a vegetarian, I haven't really tried them at lunch time.  My husband has had their mushu chicken , Mongolian chicken and few other dishes and he tells me that the food is average.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Crispy tofu with young bamboo
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Mongolian chicken..
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Inside

_y_Ru0xxd0bjFaxsfID5pw.text: I've been coming here for dim sum for years and keep discovering still more delicious goodies.  Shrimp is my favorite, and for me the pinnacle is the seafood roll, with a bit of cream cheese inside the crispy crust.  The only problem with dim sum here is how to choose from the array of delights as the carts approach the table.  The solution is to get takeout to bring home after lunch, enough for a couple days of culinary joy.  The staff also can provide a takeout menu with handy lists that can be filled out in advance.  I haven't yet, but am prepared to go by with a list to present for a takeout order, if my ongoing craving for this food becomes overwhelming and I have no plans for a sit-down lunch.  Being from San Francisco, Chinese food has always been part of my food fantasies.  I'm so glad I discovered Phoenix Palace so I can experience the best.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Seafood rolls and sesame balls.
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Shumai and other delicacies.

LoWpZzNg1G3_sUcBuLSYaA.text: The best dim sum is in Los Angeles! They were extremely understaffed when we arrived. We had 7 people in our group and were seated probably 30 minutes after waiting on a Sunday morning. The servers were doing their best and they were really friendly!   We paid $115-ish for the whole table. I'd come back if given the chance. The food there reminded me of ones in San Gabriel Valley for sure.

i6b-Jtmx405NTWuZsqi-XQ.text: Awesome place for dim sum. Moved here two years ago and we have gotten consistent good food. Dim sum is very hard to find a place that knows what they are doing. My caution try to pace your self. My wife loves to point at too many items when the carts roll by. Better to eat them hot.  If you order the duck or roast pork to go make sure you call in advance to make sure they have some. It can sell out.

nEH5mKXvB2XrZu9vDeXjng.text: Very good dim sum. Not truly exemplary but it was flavorful and filling without being overly salty or anything. The price was good but the selection was kinda so so (I have been told its better on weekends, we went around noon on a Monday) and the service was alright. There were only two carts going so it was pretty slow. One of the ladies was also pretty mean.  Decent dim sum though!

vkGC1pPMhD39WTCAdYqGXg.text: The food is good and multiple. You have a lot of options!! We always enjoy the dim sum in the beautiful weekend!

T-rpwylxVfJTIST8SIfzFA.text: Tried dim sum here today. We are dim sum fanatics and try it in most cities we visit. I won't even compare Seattle or San Francisco dim sum - that is a league beyond AZ.   However several of the dishes are pretty good: shumai, shrimp dumplings, and baked barbecue pork buns.  The rest are average. The staff is great, friendly, and attentive. The vibe is fine.   C-Fu used to be better but they became pretty mediocre several years ago. This is better than the current C- Fu, but not better than the good old days.   I've never been a fan of Great Wall.   So, the question for all you local dim sum fans is "where is the best dim sum in Phoenix these days?"  We can't find first rate fare in this city.

u4TSzbv6CIIQ_2my--hIHA.text: (Lyric - Janet Jackson - Love Will Never Do (Without You)) Phoenix Palace I have tried before To replace as my Dim Sum place Never did I have a doubt It's Dim Sum I can't do without  They said it wouldn't last We had to prove them wrong Cause I've eaten in the past That hunger will always be without you  Phoenix Palace I have tried before To replace as my Dim Sum place Never did I have a doubt It's Dim Sum I can't do without I feel better after a meal with you Cause no other place around Has quite the same Yum Yum (ha ha ha!) Like you do do do do...  Phoenix Palace is an old school Dim Sum joint located in the heart of what I call little Chinatown.  Off Dobson and Warner this little corner in Chandler is a mecca for Asian businesses, aside from your LA Fitness on the Northwest corner.  Phoenix Palace is in the same corner as Lee Lee's Market; where you can explore all food ingredients from the Orient.    I'm a dim sum lover and I wish I could go every weekend, but that would totally destroy my diet!  Needless to say, Phoenix Palace is one of my favorite dim sum places in Phoenix.  They offer up some traditional products like Siu Mai, Nai Wong Bao, Phung Chows, and Cha Sui Baos.  Moreover, they also have some newer products and I gather it's for the more American guest like fried noodles, fried rice and calamari.  All good, but some times I wish they would just stick with tradition.    Overall, the dim sum is pretty good and one of the best in my opinion of what we can get in Phoenix.  It'll get the job done as they say, but don't expect it to blow your mind away.  Service here has improved through the years and afterwards you can always stop by Lee Lee's to get your Asian groceries.  Just a skip and a hop away is a Boba place so you might as well get your entire Asian fix on and done! - Enjoy

JYtQXHjWyMzFt9eueCeBPQ.text: My lovely Japanese friend is always inviting me to the latest and greatest of finds and this one is great. I have no idea what anything was called and I have never had dim sum but this was great! the best was this custard cookie thing, my good it was amazing.... So I recommend it. I just pointed to stuff on the carts and it seamed to work.

AvV3-S3tsjTy3RrVC7D_WQ.text: pros: - huge variety of dimsum (especially on weekends) - high quality meat - yummy desserts  cons: - metallic water - some dishes are fresher than others  i've been pleased each time i've had dim sum here. i order mango custard buns, sesame seed balls with red bean paste, steamed barbeque pork buns, sticky rice, shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice noodles, and chow mein.  the mango custard buns are sweet and the bread is fluffy. it is topped with crispy coconut shavings, and makes the perfect dessert. the sesame balls are also great for dessert, as they have a crunchy outside and a sweet inside consisting of glutinous rice flour and red bean paste. the steamed barbeque pork buns are a favorite of mine, as they melt in your mouth and you can detect a hint of honey along with the nice pork flavor. the sticky rice has a bit of a bitter flavor but a great consistency, and has a fill of chicken and a piece of a hot dog in the middle. the shrimp dumplings have a bit too fishy a flavor for my taste but are otherwise good. the shrimp rice noodles didn't have this problem, and the sauce they were topped with had a perfect amount of salt and flavor. tastly, the chow mein was surprisingly flavorful and i loved the large amount of bean sprouts that were in it.   my main complaint about this place was actually the water. it tastes pretty metallic, as if it had come straight out of the tap. otherwise, this place is great for dimsum. go on the weekends for the food carts and greatest variety of dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. A view of the restaurant from the side booth
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Mango custard buns
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Sesame seed balls with red bean paste

F3ckJkjtfgYzA5Hxx0jm0A.text: First of all, to be clear, I have really high standard for dim sum.   Spare ribs, Egg&pork congee and chicken feet are the must-have for me every time. So I first tried them. They were good but not best, a small step down from Great wall or China King. But the Egg tart and Pineapple buns really impressed me! If the Pineapple bun served right from oven, it must be heavenly good!!  The service was fine, but no one served water until we ordered chrysanthemum tea. But this place was not so crowed like Great Wall or China King. We didn't have to wait in lines even on Sunday morning.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Chicken feet
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. Spare ribs. It tastes good but the ribs are not fresh enough

_hoykhXg9WC4BlQo-Zl6Kg.text: The service was excellent. I was surprised that the carts came around so frequently and our tea pot would be filled the moment it became empty. There was this guy coming out with special dishes, he's a good marketer btw. Lol.   As far as food goes, it was good, not great but it was more than just okay. The salt and pepper squid was too breaded in my opinion, but the congee was surprisingly pretty awesome! The eggplant was also a favorite of mine. The Chinese broccoli was overcooked and shriveled to me so it was a bit rubbery and difficult to eat.

F-OQnD9V1kZ2snxbL4ERnA.text: The best baked pork buns that we've ever had and we've had lots of pork buns. Service was wonderful.

-LnpKtpnqoGpgCtG4NAQKw.text: This is my first time to try this restaurant for dinner. I ordered some BBQ pork and chicken, saw the cook dropped the meat on the dirty table but he still tried to give that to me. I asked him please do not - and he sneaked that piece of meat back into the pan to be sold to others! I also ordered a plate of tofu per their recommendation. None are tasting good.  I later got very bad food poisoning from this dinner and I continue to throw up the next day when I was in airplane with a trip I must take.   I will avoid this restaurant.

sG08AhK8pMZsBzPssPXOdw.text: I've been doing monthly Dim Sum events with a group of people and I am a loyal fan of this institution.   Since I've only had Dim Sum, I will only mention the Dim Sum service. The carts speed by you very quickly but slowly die off in frequency at the end of your meal.  The only reason I feel that this is the best Dim Sum in the Valley is that they take reservations unlike their competitors. I can have a group of 20 people and they will reserve no problem, well, at least when I schedule at 10:30am.  The golden gem in the Dim Sum selection is the curry tendon, melt-in-your mouth tendon that has a great curry flavor. No other Dim Sum place in Phoenix has it.

USO9FGBV-tDzKc8SYFjRaw.text: Was looking for a dim sum place in AZ and this was it. 20 miles from Phoenix but worth the visit. It has all the usual dim sum treats and also sells barbecue pork and duck to go. Be sure to be seated in the large main dining room as we were seated in a rear banquet room and it was hard to get the attention of the servers and their rolling carts. Yes get there early or expect a wait at peak brunch on weekends. Service was good and prices reasonable. Bring friends so you can try more things.  There is also the LeeLee Chinese Market in the same shopping mall and worth a visit on its own.

m8TqpV1BspaT6aVJ7_H5Pg.text: Went in for Dim Sum  Food...meh.  Service...meh.  The real big issue is that I don't speak Chinese and the folks that work there don't speak a lot of English.  As such, figuring out what exactly you were getting, or not getting, was somewhere between hard and impossible to figure out.

RbzTouXPpklsFNrvDqZ_7A.text: Bad food, waitress had a bad attitude and the won Ton soup was watery, stay away you might sick from eating here

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

qEylQyxdb_HNiKRmV99bqQ.text: I was in the mood for some Dim Sum this past weekend and supposedly this was the best option for Dim Sum in the Phoenix area so I had to check it out for myself. It was fairly crowded when I got there but I was still able to get a table quickly. I did notice a lot of Asian families dining in near my table which is probably a good sign. As for the Dim Sum I decided on getting the Har Gow, Shu Mai, and the sticky rice. Out of the three that I tried the sticky rice was my favorite, although even then I have had much better elsewhere. The Har Gow was just okay I thought and the Shu Mai was not very good, would probably pass on getting that next time.  Overall I would say that Phoenix Palace is an okay spot to get Dim Sum but mainly because there are not too many other options in the area. I did notice that they do takeout for Dim Sum which could be a good idea when I stop by in the area next time. The service here I would say is typical of other Dim Sum restaurants, although I would add that I did feel a bit rushed when dining in.

_iWsu_LB_O3pZwbcybudiw.text: the food is as great as usual~ no wonder why it gets the voted best dim sum in Phoenix~ Love the sesame ball and shaomai~

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. menu price list
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. decor
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. food, delicious food~

K5opeKaf47qcWdOrp1SNyg.text: This is the most starz I can give this place I have been 8 or so times and it's always mediocre at best we walked in today and had the sweets cart pull up first shortly the next came the sticky rice and shrimp balls ok the usual and then........................... nothing for 10 or more minutes finally after having to ask for more the next cart shows up umm ok shrimp balls again ... ya they also had tripe, chicken feet. Shu mi and a few other Asian delicacy but not my cup of tea no baked hum bow , BBQ pork, veg balls , seafood long noodle thing .......  oh and all the 100 year old wait staff seemed really pissed off

nDHOgUEF1oh-QXKbKZsN3w.text: The place has the basics for dim sum, there are steamed pork buns, ribs, stripes, chicken feet, shumai, shrimp dumplings etc. They are all quite flavorful and standard on their tastes. The pork buns don't use a traditional bread but the bun they use taste quite sweet. The tripe is good and their other beef intestine dish is a bit salty for my taste but still acceptable. The food is average for dim sum, but it is pretty decent for dim sum in Arizona. The service is not great I had to ask 3 or 4 times for shrimp rolls and the tea refill took a while to arrive. It was pretty slow on business too so there seemed to just be a lack of workers at the time even though we went at around lunch time. I would say Sunday would probably have better service but you would have to wait for a while. I have also had dinner here and they have better quality food as well as service then.

nhQ9z_dWWJKPnkYdoepoCQ.text: I don't know what it is about dim sum here in the Valley, but I just haven't found one that is even close to half-way decent.  The pork rice wrapped in leaves was pretty good, as were the shrimp dumplings, but the pork dumplings, the egg custard, and the taro root, which is usually my favorite, were pretty bland.  The fried rice and noodle dishes that we had for the table were also very bland.   I wish that my first choice, Pho Van, had been open.  The things you do when you're hungry and don't want to get back in the car.

eG7C6TRlkLOokeHfeekC_Q.text: At first I only came here for dinner getting plenty of entrees but I really enjoyed the shrimp noodles and other lo mein items. Now I come only for dim sum for their wonderful shrimp & pork dumplings & rolls and I don't remember the names of the other items but it's so great and very affordable for large quantities.

kFFWaIlVG9SSRHZy0h4Tgw.text: Good choice for dim sum. Prompt efficient service, good food and reasonable prices.

iUGRNJ0l99c3ak_Y_A6DZg.text: As far as Chinese buffets go, this is one of the best.  However, the downside to that is the price - you'll be paying about $14 per person (plus the cost of sodas if you want them).  If this was $5 cheaper, I would've given them 4 stars.  Regardless, it's a fun place to go to.  One of my favorite things about this place is that they just have an enormous selection of different foods.  They have lots of the standard Chinese buffet foods you would expect, but they also have sushi, a few different kinds of buns and dumplings, and then just random things that I would assume are fairly authentic.  I've had pig ears, chicken feet, and jellyfish here, so if you want to try something new or disturb your squeamish friends, you have a lot of opportunity for that.  Last time I went they didn't have any jellyfish out which was disappointing because honestly, jellyfish is pretty delicious.  If they have it while you're there, try it out.  There are generally a LOT of Asian people at Phoenix Palace Buffet, which to me seems like a good sign that this is at least semi-authentic.  Also, they have a gigantic space in their building and have way, way too much seating, so you shouldn't have to worry about trying to find enough chairs and tables for a large group.  One last thing - don't forget to try the lotus seed paste buns.  They're a semi-sweet dessert bun and they're awesome.

uYH1Z7pnEiOVa5AjTH2n6w.text: beware of the hidden  65 cent surcharge per person for tea even if you don't drink tea?  really.  The crazy thing is, i'm sure no one even notices the extra cost because who checks the bill?  When I mentioned it to the cashier, she was stuttering and stammering and started to back pedal and said  "oh, is this your 1st time?  we can remove it from the bill"  I said forget it, keep it.  i usually tip 20-30% but i'll just let them keep their meager 65 per charge.    yeah, really worth losing a customer for?  my 4 year old daughter even gets the gratuitus tea party charge and she only drinks water.  gone are the $2.15 per item flat rate (can you say bait and switch?)  $2.35 PER so now they're no different from the rest of the dim sum places.  as sneaky as C-FOO trying to strong arm the 15% gratuity (which failed miserably and lost us and about 100 of our friends as customers)  so in a down economy, you're supposed to raise your prices and sneak in stealthy surcharges?  it's the chinese way i guess  back to china king for us.  sorry china king for being disloyal with having a brief and sordid affair with the palace.  will you forgive us? haha

il6v5tC_3sXZU7YwFzyvBA.text: Went on the weekend for dim sum and was not disappointed. They have a wide variety of traditional dim sum items. Although they seem to specialize more in the pasties and buns. They will also prepare traditional Chinese dishes during dim sum. Our favorite that we order as a side dish is Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce. If you have never had dim sum then try it. It is a n experience you won't forget.

tdrbY2bUhwQ9hMg4WuW34A.text: My boyfriend and I are travelers going to the Grand Canyon. Tempe is our first stop. We went there right after we landed. The food is very very good. Service is so so. But anyway I like it a lot.

fUmECl4re1p05d3hWE8gQA.text: I went looking for the typical "not real Chinese" buffet on a Sunday and found this place.  Never had Dim Sum before so thought this would be different. From the moment we sat down, the carts were on us putting stuff on the table and having us choose from a selection that I honestly cannot tell you what I ate.  I just said yes to what looked good.  I wasn't disappointed, but I can't tell you what I ate! :)  I do know that I accidentally said yes to the chicken feet thinking is was just fried chicken.  I'm adventurous, but that was too much so I left it.  Without even asking, they were cool enough to take it off of the bill.  We all laughed about how the server's children loved it, and they were really great.  The cart ladies struggle with English a lot, but that's OK as again, I just said yes to what looked good.  Overall the price was pretty reasonable and I tried a lot of food. I'll be back!

9DQr56505Wyjl09pD2DKng.text: My default place to go for Dim-sum on weekend.    The best dim-sum on the east valley.  China King is closed, but Phoenix Palace is a bit cleaner.  The take out counter is also great for getting a whole roasted duck/chicken and a few pastries.

E3O1035Ho6HZHhjl8xG-fQ.text: Hello awesome! Love this restaurant - their dim sum is delicioussss! They've got great selections, and I love being able to head over to their bakery area and snag a couple bun things to go. Service is not so great - but seriously - what do you expect, it's really not unusual for this sort of setup. I would give it 5 stars except that I hate their char-siapao - the bbq bun - this is one of my faves, since I was a little kid and theirs taste blech. I go here often, and stuff my face - awesome food for an awesome price.

fbtbdQlCaz6zbo5Oix5lBA.text: I don't know why I haven't written a review of this place yet.  Been there at least 5 times; well I do enjoy dim sum; and really enjoy Phoenix Palace.  The moon cakes; are wonderful pastries that I always have to get when I'm there.  The only draw back is the "waiting" area; it's not very large and just like Great Wall; it can get very crowded very fast.  I'm definately a fan!!!

_Ig8Bp-8FOZYBzQkzLClgQ.text: Best Dim Sum in the East Valley. Try to get there as early as 11AM for fresh and full cart of Dim Sum. If you go there late there won't be much left. I love baked bbq pork buns. Custard buns are great too, more custard than flours! Love it! Service can be slow on the weekends due to the big crowds.

5nt0jStnfujK2w2QnRMKrg.text: I have been here for dim sum couple times, good service and good food. BUT.. a recent visit to Phoenix Palace gave me a brand new view about this place. My friend and I had 2 waters and 6 dim sum items. When the bill came, we noticed an item on the bill says "2 guests: $1.70". When we asked the server why, she replied "we charge money for water."  This restaurant CHARGES $0.85 for every water they give out to customer! This is not bottle water, simply water from the tap in a plastic cup. For this reason, I will NOT return to this place, there are plenty other dim sum places in town will gladly provide free water to customers, like any other restaurant in AZ.

zcJIflQEk6AgKbpjdYwv7Q.text: Not the cleanest place but the dishes are awesome! Service is great, too.

EMPsxAJQrdctGXDd07JRxg.text: Not a buffet, but really good restaurant overall. Definitely not a "five-star" establishment in the traditional sense, but if you want good Chinese food at good prices with a True Chinese restaurant feel, this is a good place.

H769cdVC2WhXLiZq-MLaGw.text: Wow!  Nice surprise.  We are from Scottsdale and had to be in the Chandler area for something, so we decided to take advantage the Asian restaurant area and this was the one we chose.  It's pretty, quite large, and they were open on Monday and were serving Dim Sum.  It was a real treat.  The noodle part of the dim sum was quite good, not to thick, but also not delicate.  The individual dim sum that we tried....like 6 different ones...I would have to say, were tasty, nicely wrapped and steamed.  We are picky! and we are anxious to go back on a Saturday as they have even more options.  Yes, we would drive 15 miles to go back there, it was that good!

v8he6kE8v1krW6pVrN3FXQ.text: Absolutely terrible. Had 2 meals delivered, this was horrible. Both dishes. They should be paying me.  I ordered delivery and due to the minumum was required to spend a certain dollar amount, no problem, ordered two entrees, figured I'd have the other the next day.  The food delivered was as if it had been sitting in a bin for many hours as everything came dried out, cold and no flavor.  the sweet and sour shrimp didn't even have the sweet and sour sauce.  they gave these little to go packets of hot sauce and duck sauce.  First and last time I eat from this place.  I can't find away to take away the one star I've given this place.  Oh well

TvDpTNvAItbNPauwFJ3UVA.text: First of all, if you are going to have dim sum, go early during the weekend because that is when the quality and freshness are best. Also go in a large group so that the bill is less for everyone. I have been here a few times on Sunday mornings around 10 am and never have to worry about waiting for a table. They have a decent selection of dim sum dished. My usual's are the "footballs", the Hau gau, and the taro cakes, all of which are decent. If you wait long enough, you might be able to get your hands on the coconut pastries called "snow balls" which are very enjoyable. In a hungry group of 4, you can expect to pay $20-25 total as a group and not want to eat anything for the next 6-12 hours.

tZBBdrlGdfYR-KmK0FXCrA.text: We were visiting friends in Scottsdale and they brought us to eat here - twice.  We had a great dinner here on new years eve with my favorites - hot and sour soup and peking duck (among other things).  They had a huge private party going on, but pretty much gave us a private room with karaoke and served us pretty quickly. Despite getting here late, we still made it out of here in time to celebrate on our own.  We then returned for dim sum and were not disappointed. We had to wait a bit because we arrived late, but it was worth it.  The food was fresh and hot - and they had these desserts (snowballs or something) that we haven't found anywhere else. Our friends come here every weekend - and they are the ultimate foodies - so we were not disappointed.

3q0IG38GvhDkPnCZurCVJg.text: My parents came into town and insisted on having Chinese food, but I told them that I didn't think there would be any authentic Chinese food in the middle of a desert. Well...  After stopping by the Lee Lee supermarket next door (uber Asian!) my parents and I wandered into this place, unsure of what it would hold... and lo and behold! Dim sum? Cantonese speaking servers?   I was pleasantly surprised by how authentic this place was, with the push-around carts and the loud boss running around poking fun at his employees. Everything about this place made me feel like I was back home in NY eating in Chinatown...   CONS: I got a little stomach ache from the 'lo mai gai' or rice wrapped in lotus leaf and unfortunately suffered from that for the rest of the day. I also think the seafood could have been fresher... Also, not too many choices but then again, if there's only a few authentic Chinese restaurants in the area, I won't complain if it's the run-of-the-mill dishes...  PROS: The 'dan tat' or egg tart is pretty good, though I do prefer my crust to be a little more moist.

84dZgxzhNeBCb6KrsCkJyQ.text: This place used to be good with fresh food and most of all economical. During recent months the food is cold and they raised their prices. What used to be a class A, now is class D and they even charge you for tap water.

FX_6C9nyqeCLL9074fu8CA.text: It's not a buffet, just the regular dim sum carts. Not very bustling and had to wait around a bit for carts (not slow, just not back-to-back like it is at busier places) but I like their sticky rice and pineapple buns a lot. Everything else a tiny notch above C-Fu just because it's slightly less oily and the prices are lower. :)

SFVIsDb3AHQKG7pDcxjeAg.text: Dimsum is just okay. Thats all i can say since ive always ordered To Go.

SlZ-hZO6nOqrFj1DPRICeg.text: I usually go to a different, nearby Chinese restaurant for dim sum. But, somebody recommended Phoenix Palace to me instead, saying that it put the other place to shame. Uh, wrong! It's the exact opposite actually.  The selection of dim sum at lunchtime on a Tuesday was dismal. A handful of dishes, and they seemed quite unwilling to prepare anything they didn't have already in the cart. The items I did try were quite lacking in quality and flavor...although they did seem to be somewhat fresh (to their credit).  If you're looking for delicious dim sum--and a good selection of it--try someplace else. Phoenix Palace is not the place to go. I won't return.

Y-G4XkIM0sXfVYIVXN-vCw.text: Amazing! Dim sum is great, and can be as adventurous or as tame as you want it.  The selections on the carts are numerous and inexpensive.  And they don't just make the rounds once and disappear, they keep coming until you either explode or summon the willpower to say no.  I always eat too much at these places.  I can't say no to bbq pork buns, or bbq duck (they have these hanging in the front window for sale at reasonable prices if you're feeling the need.  I'm the only duck commander at my house so I usually have to pass, but they'll do 1/4 to the whole thing.  I'll be back).  I ate until I physically couldn't any more.  Everything from dumplings to shrimp toast to green beans to chicken feet-- if there's something you want, they have it on one of these carts rolling around.  And if you don't know what something is, they're happy to tell you.  This is super helpful if you're new to dim sum, or even if you've had it before but spot something new to try.  I just wish they'd cut me off before I need a bucket! Be prepared to wait a bit, but not too long to lose interest and move on.  Be prepared for an awesome meal and good service.  Our tab for two large mammals who ate to the point of misery was under $40, so its reasonably priced.  The only drawback is that they only do dim sum for lunch.  You gotta drag your butt outa bed, but its so worth it!

e7SXaWhex2-unPfRki0CFQ.text: First off, I hate it when people aren't sitting yet or have our drinks and all the dim sum ladies come attack you with their carts! One person tells the ladies no we don't want anything yet and then they go ask someone else at the table and they stand there for the longest minute!   The food is pretty decent. There were some choices here that are not offered here in Sacramento.  I like how everyone understands English.  Employees are nice.

Fhpo9F8oZ4Fev6xKZytMbw.text: The service is so bad here!  The dim sum is ok.  It takes forever to get them to come to the table for more Dim Sum.  I rather go to other local places for Dim Sum

Enb6E9_v_CwPu83dbGvM3A.text: After dim summing at the Chinese Cultural Complex and the Great Wall in Phoenix, I feel confident declaring this the Valley winner for Dim Sum. I've been here a number of times over the years and have had a delicious experience each time. The key is to get there before 11:00AM so you don't have a long wait. Any time after 11:15AM pretty much guarantees the place will be packed to the brim.  Also, they run out of snowballs after 11:00AM and that is pretty much the most awesome pastry ever. PPB has loads of carts roaming around so you are never without food, and the prices are great. Obviously the bigger your party the lower your bill will be, no matter how much more you order. It's dim sum insanity!   Seriously, who can eat 'regular' chinese food again after a healthy dose of steamed dumplings, soups, chicken feet and light fluffy pastries?   Do yourself a favor and make the drive to Phoenix Palace Buffet!

IBSzg8vMp6EyrD3m6eDamg.text: Worst Chinese place I have been to, by far. Ordered the Vegetable Chow Mein and requested they also add tofu. Tofu was plain, drenched in water, and sticky. No flavor whatsoever, Broccoli was half cooked- if that. Would never come back here again. Service staff was also rude and inattentive. DO NOT eat here. Waste of time and money.

_ED1QsZOf9II2p51xJl2yA.text: Dimsum! Weekends are so busy, these people are legit cantonese/chinese which if you do not know is as authentic as you can get.  Dim Sum is a Hong Kong brunch (cantonese people).  I am a big fan of this place because all of your yummy dim sum items come out piping hot! I have gone to places where they are just warm.  We are really looking forward to trying dinner here one day.  Will become a regular here for dimsum :)

ZGR5CJ7Mw-MBoa8eAA8D_w.text: This is our go-to place for dim sum with a good selection. On weekends, they have a much more extensive selection and many more carts running around. The servers are fast and ready to get you selections not on the carts (we always order some type of veg to go with our usual spread of gluttony). My only tiny gripe is that they don't have dou-miao (pea shoots), but we did like their stir fried green beans. We've only lived here for not quite a month and have been here 3 times plus it's a 25 min drive...

koDPdAmzG_-j6VhhVQC34Q.text: The dim sum at phoenix palace is pretty good, we enjoyed everything.  I ordered something new in my book and that was the curry tendon- it was a bit chewy and was lacking the curry flavor but overall not bad.  My favorite part about dining here is when you sit down and all the ladies with their dim sum carts flock toward you!!

aNC0TV4T143uYndWhWVcJQ.text: UPDATE: Food poisoning. Never returning.  This place gets a 5 star review for being the best dim sum restaurant in the valley.  Sure I've had better in SF, but this is still pretty good.   Major bonus points for the takeout counter.  I don't know what most of this stuff is called, but I know what it looks like.  I was able to give the girl a description and she knew exactly what it was.  I've now got pictures on my phone for future visits. I think it's a step above their competitor on the other side of the street, but their competitor seems to have a wider selection.  At least in the carts that are going around.   Bonus points for having a gelato shop a few doors down.  Not that you'll be hungry when you leave.

2KE21CONw49iR2phr3JbxA.text: This place has me seriously reconsidering where I live and contemplating a move to Chandler. This is where I find cultural hotspots like asian markets, boba cafes and finally....dim sum! The hubs and I tried dim sum in Central Phoenix at the Chinese Cultural Center - no bueno. We went once and never had an urge to go back.  We had almost given up hope in finding a decent dim sum place when we strolled upon Phoenix Palace Buffet.   Dim Sum ends at 3pm and we stopped in at 2:30pm. They were still welcoming and stocked with fresh food choices. We tried their sticky rice, bbq pork buns, shrimp dumplings, rice noodles and taro cakes. One bite and we knew this place was legit.   We are sooooo looking forward to when we can go there again. The only downside is that it's a good 30 minute drive to this area so we can't enjoy dim sum on a weekly basis like we used to in SoCal. Bummer.

Kv1okXUfT7-BFHgn38sSxw.text: I prefer Phoenix Palace to C-Fu Gourmet for dim sum. Judging by the wait on Sunday mornings, I'm not the only one! I love their bbq pork buns, dumplings, stir fry noodles, sticky rice with pork, and desserts. They have this one dessert that is like a sweet almond milk soup with a pastry crust - really yummy and unique. The servers don't speak great English, but that's ok as long as the food is good!

rrg_wHFxjzSFpRRHUzhPiA.text: Great, every time. INCREDIBLY CHEAP!!!!  I always get the chicken feet, bao, and some steamed yellow pork thing.  ( I never remember the name).  Always the same quality, always sweet people that work there. I love it...  Actually... Now I want to eat there... Damn.

7PB1VK1WHZ_6eLwQDGmImQ.text: Ok, so this place isn't my favorite dim sum ever (reigning title goes to Yank Sing in San Francisco).  But when I get that craving for some delicious carb focused dim sum, Phoenix Palace is where I go.  It's the best we know of in the valley to feed our fix and definitely affordable.  bbq pork buns are my favorite :)    So if you're looking for some good dim sum in the valley, head here, because you won't find better unless you head to SF or China.

1InSHLzkIB4HxJbY2gkDpA.text: The food is always as expected but the service has gone absolutely downhill from ok.... to "did they just put our chopsticks and napkins on the table while it was soaking wet from what appeared to be a stinky dish rag they wiped it with?"  We decided to try it again and used the private room in the back for a reserved party.... it was filthy.  When brought to the manager's attention,  he was not even apologetic and looked angry at us! The customers for suggesting that it be cleaned up before our guests arrive.  I think I'm done with the place.... at least for awhile unless some things change.

OnjB1EXjGdF7ZvWVMefymw.text: Went there several times. Came away thoroughly satisfied every time. :) I usually don't like dim sum that much, mind you.

VEKj3MdTn3IPPmKTSbkELg.text: Who doesn't like Dim Sum? For those who are unfamiliar with Dim Sum; essentially, it is a type of Chinese cuisine in which was modified down from what would only be served to kings and queens as a delicate to something everyone can enjoy. Ideally, it is best to eat this for breakfast and/or brunch.  Anyway, I believe this place serves one of the best Dim Sum in the Phoenix Area.  What better than to have little Asian ladies push around their Dim Sum carts around to your table and serve you food. Anything from steamed to baked; it is as good as it gets. Several of my favorite dishes are: Pork Dumplings, Shrimp Dumplings, Bean Curd (it sounds weird but pretty good for vegetarians), Beef and Shrimp Rice Noodles with soy sauce, Chicken Feet (normally, Americans don't like this but give it a shot), baked goods like custard buns, custard tarts, pineapple custard buns, coconut buns. These are just a few that I've named; there are many more delicious goodies.  Everything must be downed with a cup of warm tea. Mmmm. Yum.  This place is cleaner than most Chinese restaurants and their customer service (even for dinner) is not bad.

kjyggjQ-0-cqXtBVOtk4Gg.text: They serve diversity dim-sum. I love all of them! I think this is the best dim-sum place in Arizona.  I'm not from the southeast China, so this is my best personal experience.

FTo0vNEaFPQzCX55dGhMvA.text: Ordered takeout dimsum because crowds wait long to be seated. I usually get har gow, siu mai, chao siu bao. Siu mai is outstanding better than the ones in LA. The bao is small and hargow meh. Have also tried turnip cake and gai lan in garlic sauce which is good sometimes but pricey.

S1COt9pWhfIWRdkm3--aNg.text: Thanks to Ted L. for posting the picture of the rude guy in your review dated 5-29-2016.  I can now confirm that guy was also rude to me during my recent visit.  I am fairly certain that guy is actually the owner or co-owner of the restaurant.  He has never been too friendly before, but now he turned rude.    I can understand/tolerate an occasional rough behavior from an underpaid/overloaded employee (incidentally this also happened at Phoenix Palace sometime ago), but for an owner to be rude to his customers is totally unacceptable.  No one should feel being insulted or harassed while patronizing a small business.

olU44gzAVDCxKiCpkm4t0A.text: If you've been to an authentic Dim Sum restaurant, Phoenix Palace is a great 2nd placer, although not my top choice. Those pushing around the carts are so friendly and their dishes are fairly good, although sometimes can seem old like they've been out a while. The customer service is impeccable though! I love that my friends and I can ask the waiters and waitresses in both Mandarin and Cantonese exactly what we'd like. This place is good for the family and great for larger parties! I haven't explored other Dim Sum restaurants in the greater Phoenix area, but this isn't a bad start.

lJgkWe3JDD4AyJYdqFzlAA.text: This was a long drive from Cave Creek, but we wanted dim sum!  Arrived mid-afternoon Sunday and there were HOARDS milling around outside restaurant.  That was bad.  Good news was mostly Asian, so we felt that indicated some good eats and worth the wait.  But there was very little wait.  They have a great system---despite the numbers, we were seated within 10 minutes.    The dim sum carts came around at the perfect intervals and we hardly passed up a one, so I can't even tell you what-all we had, except it was uniformly hot and good.  The dim sum ladies didn't have a lot of English, but mostly they could explain what the dish(es) were on their carts, and if not---what the heck, right?    It was just so much fun, and we ate and ate and ate and still ended up with a super-reasonable bill.  We will totally plan another road trip to Chandler and Phoenix Palace---and it's the perfect opportunity to stop in at Lee-Lee's International Market to pick up some exotic stuff for the pantry!

wu0u_mVVNfeiYj0a8Vifbg.text: My favorite dim sum restaurant in the valley! Food is not greasy, carts come by frequently, and service is great. Be prepared to wait a bit if you go during the high volume times on the weekend- but it's well worth the wait! We come here at least once a month... and when we're done eating, we hop over to LeeLee's market and the boba tea next door for some treats & shopping. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States
Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

rD75_cgPJ6ipY-jOeomW8Q.text: Whenever I'm craving dim sum, this is my goto spot!   You can go wrong any of the dishes. The clams, seasoned asparagus, ha gao or shumai, fried chicken, chicken feet are all items that I order.  My favorite is the ha gao, I can eat about two orders of it. For those who don't know it's a pork dumpling and shumai is a shrimp dumpling. Both are my top two choices!   Hot tea always goes well with the meal, as well. It can get busy here on the weekends so plan to come early, if you have a bigger party then most likely if you have to wait. If it's just 2 people you'll get seated faster.

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States. So much food!

Y5rVwByVOhoy2p4y0of49A.text: Ordered 4 dinners at Phoenix Palace...got home...no rice. So I call, because I don't know if it doesn't come with.   They forgot. So I drive back and tell them I will be there in 10. They are OUT of rice. Can I wait? Well I am sure not going to leave without it.  Been waiting for 15 minutes so far.

hZ4LAcjGgG_CHjuWkLVYeA.text: Came here for brunch and our Dim Sum fix for the weekend with my boyfriend. Came around 12pm and the wait was about 5 minutes - not too bad especially on a holiday. The food wasn't the best, but it wasn't the worse I've had - pretty decent for Arizona. Pricing wasn't bad either; it was a total of $37 including tips and tax for two people. We had the marinated chicken feet (tasty and steamed well), Siu mai, ha gao, steamed pork ribs, and a few other dishes. We had around a total of 11 dishes, which isn't bad for the price. They also have a to-go area for you to order and pick-up. Lots of parking in the plaza as well. Service was friendly to me, but I spoke mostly in Chinese when ordering so it helped. Will return for our dim sum fixes :)

photos.caption: Photo of Phoenix Palace - Chandler, AZ, United States

afiLCQOnfjuzEopxD-b3Aw.text: Ehh..definitely was not impressed with any dishes I ordered today! Maybe..just maybe the porridge. But even so, the food was ehhh.

Xq4g7cyOxD08ZMRDp5JyHw.text: Our go to dim sum place! Lots of great selections, one of the best in the valley! The shu mai is a family fave! And the service is also good. Might be a 20-30 mins wait on the weekends.

eg0rQuKZMJ7xrjlGgvKOgg.text: 2.9 stars - sub-standard dimsum, dishes ordered below:  ORDER Shrimp tofu - favorite dish, tofu was excellent Short ribs in black bean sauce - tasty, what you might expect Turnip cake - a bit oily but full of turnip, great flavor  Taro cake - a bit dry but loved the fresh taro, this dish can be hard to find Shao mai (siu mai) pork dumplings - decent   SKIP Rice noodle roll with shrimp (chang fen) - shrimp was juicy and tasty, the rice cake itself was  Shrimp dumplings (xia jiao) - smallest shrimp dumplings I've ever seen at any dimsum spot Shrimp dumplings with chives - had to actually send this back, chives might've been rotten, which gave the dumplings a sour taste  On the upside, service was pretty good, servers do a good job of rounding the large restaurant with carts. Good for groups, takes reservations.

rA8Xrbfia6suXDWk_bSrSQ.text: We come here all the time. No real issues just the usual which is the wait during the weekend for dim sum. Tip is when your going to Dim Sum be prepared to be aggressive in order to get attention or you will be waiting ha ha. I gave a 4 because of some staff and good food!!!

TjR9AzJTYKv33NKuQhwa5g.text: I don't have have dim sum often.. And I have tried a couple of places but I do like the food here better.. They do get busy here fast so I suggest you come right when they open.. When it does get busy, the main thing that sucks is just waiting for the carts around and of course when the cart with the dim sums u want comes I feel like we have to stock up on the ones we like bc we don't know when they are going to come again.. And I feel like the ladies that pushes the cart gets a lil aggressive and tries to force food you don't want at you and when you don't choose they get mad at you and leave.. But other than that we do like the food.. We love getting the pork buns and shu-Mai here.. Those are our top 2.. And every once in awhile I like getting the chow main , Chinese broccoli and their porridge..
